awd_titl_txt: Computing and Intersectionality (The Social and Behavioral Structures at Play for Black Women in the Computing Sciences):  An Inclusive Agenda for Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Computing and Intersectionality builds on the growing focus on gender equity in computing in the United States. The disproportionate underrepresentation of women in computing fields is an ongoing national challenge. Within that larger dialogue on inclusion, there exists a growing body of work and focus on the intersectional factors that affect women of color within the larger population of women.  The underrepresentation of women of color is more acute than the underrepresentation of women generally and the factors that contribute to that warrant exploration.  Computing and Intersectionality is timely work and addresses this phenomenon directly.

The goal of the work is to establish a standing national conference that directly addresses issues associated with women of color within the computing sciences. It is a standing meeting to explore the particular dynamics of their experiences and to assess and determine effective institutional strategies to overcome the current challenges.  Concurrent with the establishment of a standing meeting, Computing and Intersectionality develops a journal of scholarly research for both social scientists and computer scientists, to focus on the intersectional factors that affect women of color. Results from this project will inform the broadening participation and STEM+C communities on specific factors of recruiting, retention, and graduation associated with women of color in computing. It is an important complement to the larger effort on gender equity, which cannot be entirely successful if women of color are not equally successful.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
blackcomputeHER.org is a non-profit (501(c)3) dedicated to supporting computing+tech education and workforce development for Black women and girls. Our aim is to address the lack of inclusion in the computing+tech discipline by providing access to opportunity, education & training, and executive thought leadership. Our programming includes our annual conference, which welcomes Black women and allies in the computing and tech space; our Fellows Program, which is a 12-month, cohort-based, leadership development program designed to cultivate Black women leaders in computing+tech; and executive thought-leadership by partnering with other organizations to share empirical research to guide the development of programming that supports Black women experiences.

In what started as a conference program, blackcomputeHER.org, INC now leads a national, community-focused network of Black women in computing representing academia, government, industry, technology entrepreneurs, and non-profit sectors. We conduct empirical research on Black women’s experiences in computing+tech which helps us curate and scale high-impact technical and professional development programs. We have convened five conferences, starting with 24 in 2016 growing to over 200 in 2019. In 2021, we held our first completely virtual conference experiences with about 100 attendees over three days. We are also starting the fifth year of our signature Fellows Program, started under this NSF grant, which provides professional development, mentoring, and technical training for Black women (professionals and graduate students). Over 70 alumnae have participated in this program.

Major accomplishments include the following:

1- Convenved five annual conferences (2 virtual, 3 in-person) for Black women on computing+tech. These conferences are consistently attended, starting with 24 for the first convening, almost 200 for in-person conferences, and approximately 100 for the virtual conferences. 

2- Developed the blackcomputeHER Fellows Program for Black women in technical careers. This program is a year-long training and mentorshop program designed to create community and connection among Black women in (or pursuring) technical careers. Over 60 alumna have come through this program. 

3- Facilited two professional development workshops in 2022. Topics included Executive Presence and Mental Wellness for Technical Women. These workshops represent the start of a broader collection of technical workshops to continue in 2023. 

4- Won a grant as one of ten organizations that were part of The Kapor Center's Tech Done Right Program. The Kapor Center designed this program with an interest in tackling systemic exclusion facing communities of color breaking into tech. These one-time grants supported trailblazing organizations with the time and resources to experiment with collaborative models. 

4- Developed partnerships and received sponsorships with organizations, including: The Kapor Center (partner), Google (sponsor & partner), NCWIT (sponsor & partner), Intel (sponsor), HP, Inc (sponsor & partner), Thurgood Marshall College Fund (partner). 

5- Earned non-profit, 501(c)3 designation from IRS in 2019. 


Last Modified: 01/13/2023
Modified by: Jamika D Burge
